name.title: 🎫 Display name
name.description: Verbose, human readable name for the detection rule
name.example: New Abnormal Credentials added to Azure AD

internal.title: 🏦 🏦 🏦 🏦 Private references
internal.description:
Propriatary, sensible and confidential data belonging to the owner of the CoreTIDE instance
where the object was modelled on, and which cannot be shared.

restricted.title: 🔐 🔐 🔐 🔐 Restricted references
restricted.description:
Properties propriatary to the owner of the CoreTIDE instance where the object was created,
but which may be shared with a defined list of approved counterparts.

reports.title: 📰 📰 📰 📰 Intelligence Reports
reports.description: Registry of reports uploaded to this CoreTIDE instance

uuid.title: 🔑 🔑 🔑 🔑 🔑 🔑 UUID
uuid.description: According to UUIDv4 specification. You can use https://www.uuidgenerator.net/version4 to generate UUIDs.

tlp.title: 🚦 🚦 🚦 🚦 🚦 Traffic Light Protocol
tlp.description: The Traffic Light Protocol - or short: TLP - was designed with the objective to create a favorable classification scheme for sharing sensitive information while keeping the control over its distribution at the same time.
markdownEnumDescriptions:
### ⚪ clear

🔑 **Identifier** : `TLP:CLEAR`

 







---

Recipients can spread this to the world, there is no limit on disclosure.

### 🟢 green

🔑 **Identifier** : `TLP:GREEN`

 







---

Limited disclosure, recipients can spread this within their community. Sources may use TLP:GREEN when information is useful to increase awareness within their wider community.

### 🟠 amber

🔑 **Identifier** : `TLP:AMBER`

 







---

Limited disclosure, recipients can only spread this on a need-to-know basis within their organization and its clients.

### 🟠 amber+strict

🔑 **Identifier** : `TLP:AMBER+STRICT`

 







---

Similar to TLP:AMBER, but restricts sharing to the organization only.

### 🔴 red

🔑 **Identifier** : `TLP:RED`

 







---

For the eyes and ears of individual recipients only, no further disclosure.

classification.title: 💡 💡 💡 💡 💡 Data Classification Marking
classification.description: Information Security classification for the data contained within the CoreTIDE object.
markdownEnumDescriptions:
### 💡 RESTREINT UE/EU RESTRICTED

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0001`

 



💶 **European Union Classified Information** : _In order for the Council to be able to work in all areas which require the use of EU classified information (EUCI),
it needs to have a comprehensive security system to protect this information. The Council decision on the security
rules for protecting EU classified information lays down the basic pr..._





---

The unauthorised disclosure of this information could be disadvantageous to the interests of the EU or one or more of the member states.

### 💡 CONFIDENTIEL UE/EU CONFIDENTIAL

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0002`

 



💶 **European Union Classified Information** : _In order for the Council to be able to work in all areas which require the use of EU classified information (EUCI),
it needs to have a comprehensive security system to protect this information. The Council decision on the security
rules for protecting EU classified information lays down the basic pr..._





---

The unauthorised disclosure of this information could cause exceptionally grave prejudice to the essential interests of the EU or one or more of the member states.

### 💡 SECRET UE/EU SECRET

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0003`

 



💶 **European Union Classified Information** : _In order for the Council to be able to work in all areas which require the use of EU classified information (EUCI),
it needs to have a comprehensive security system to protect this information. The Council decision on the security
rules for protecting EU classified information lays down the basic pr..._





---

The unauthorised disclosure of this information could seriously harm the essential interests of the EU or one or more of the member states.

### 💡 TRÈS SECRET UE/EU TOP SECRET

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0004`

 



💶 **European Union Classified Information** : _In order for the Council to be able to work in all areas which require the use of EU classified information (EUCI),
it needs to have a comprehensive security system to protect this information. The Council decision on the security
rules for protecting EU classified information lays down the basic pr..._





---

The unauthorised disclosure of this information could cause exceptionally grave prejudice to the essential interests of the EU or one or more of the member states.

### 💡 NATO Unclassified

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0006`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

This is applied to official information that is the property of NATO but 
does not meet the criteria for classification. Access to this information 
by non-NATO entities is permitted when such access would not be 
detrimental to NATO.


### 💡 NATO RESTRICTED

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0007`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

Applied to information whose unauthorized disclosure would be 
disadvantageous to the interests of NATO. Though similar safeguards 
are applied to FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY, OFFICIAL USE ONLY, or 
SENSITIVE, BUT UNCLASSIFIED information, NATO RESTRICTED 
is a security classification.


### 💡 NATO CONFIDENTIAL

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0008`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

Applied to information whose unauthorized disclosure would be 
damaging to NATO interests.


### 💡 NATO CONFIDENTIAL ATOMAL

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0009`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

Applied to information whose unauthorized disclosure would be 
damaging to NATO interests.

This designation is added to the NATO security classification when 
applicable. For example, COSMIC TOP SECRET ATOMAL (CTS-A).
ATOMAL information applies to U.S. RESTRICTED DATA or 
FORMERLY RESTRICTED DATA or United Kingdom Atomic 
Information released to NATO. 


### 💡 NATO SECRET

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0010`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

Applied to information whose unauthorized disclosure would cause 
serious damage to NATO.


### 💡 NATO SECRET ATOMAL

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0011`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

Applied to information whose unauthorized disclosure would cause 
serious damage to NATO.

This designation is added to the NATO security classification when 
applicable. For example, COSMIC TOP SECRET ATOMAL (CTS-A).
ATOMAL information applies to U.S. RESTRICTED DATA or 
FORMERLY RESTRICTED DATA or United Kingdom Atomic 
Information released to NATO. 


### 💡 COSMIC TOP SECRET

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0012`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

Applied to information whose unauthorized disclosure would cause 
exceptionally grave damage to NATO. COSMIC is applied to Top 
Secret material to signify it belongs to NATO. The term NATO TOP 
SECRET is not used.


### 💡 COSMIC TOP SECRET ATOMAL

🔑 **Identifier** : `DCM0013`

 



🪖 **NATO CLASSIFICATION MARKINGS** : _NATO information is information that has been generated by or for NATO, or member nation 
originated-information that has been released into the NATO security system. Information marked 
“NATO” is the property of NATO. NATO classified information contributed by a member nation 
remains the property ..._





---

Applied to information whose unauthorized disclosure would cause 
exceptionally grave damage to NATO. COSMIC is applied to Top 
Secret material to signify it belongs to NATO. The term NATO TOP 
SECRET is not used.

This designation is added to the NATO security classification when 
applicable. For example, COSMIC TOP SECRET ATOMAL (CTS-A).
ATOMAL information applies to U.S. RESTRICTED DATA or 
FORMERLY RESTRICTED DATA or United Kingdom Atomic 
Information released to NATO.

contributors.title: 👥 👥 👥 👥 👥 👥 Contributors
contributors.description: Individuals who supported creating, enriching or informing the information contained in the document.

description.title: 🔬 Detection description
description.description: Explanation of what the detection rule is detecting, in order to give context to alerts receivers.

alert_severity.title: 🌡️ MDR Alert Severity
alert_severity.description: Describes the level of attention required to handle the alert generated by the MDR.
markdownEnumDescriptions:
### 💬 Informational

🔑 **Identifier** : `SEV0001`

 







---

No severity level assigned, can suppport correlations or other metrics.

### ⬇️ Low

🔑 **Identifier** : `SEV0002`

 







---

Response trigger is not necessarily expected, but alert should be handled.

### ❗ Medium

🔑 **Identifier** : `SEV0003`

 







---

Moderate SLAs required, can be grouped into a larger investigation.

### 🔥 High

🔑 **Identifier** : `SEV0004`

 







---

Needs attention within tight SLAs alongside a comprehensive investigation.

### 🆘 Critical

🔑 **Identifier** : `SEV0005`

 







---

Immediate and targeted response required, threat to organization absolute.

playbook.title: 👣 Playbook link
playbook.description: Link to the playbook on Confluence

responders.title: ‍🚒 Alert Handling Team
responders.description: Team responsible to handle incoming security alerts
markdownEnumDescriptions:
### ‍🚒 CATCH

🔑 **Identifier** : `AHT0001`

 







---

Cybersecurity Analytics, Trending, Correlations & Hunting

### ‍🚒 CSIRC

🔑 **Identifier** : `AHT0002`

 







---

Computer Security Incident Response Centre

### ‍🚒 MARTI

🔑 **Identifier** : `AHT0003`

 







---

Malware Analysis, Research and Threat Intelligence

### ‍🚒 S1-SA

🔑 **Identifier** : `AHT0004`

 







---

Security Assurance and Vulnerability Management

configurations.title: 🛠️ Detection System Technical Setup
configurations.description: Per system setup of the detection configurations

carbon_black_cloud.title: Carbon Black Cloud Enterprise EDR
carbon_black_cloud.description:
VMware Carbon Black Enterprise EDR is an advanced threat hunting
and incident response solution delivering continuous visibility for top security
operations centers (SOCs) and incident response (IR) teams.

schema.title: Schema identifier and version
schema.description: Identifier of the schema at its current version

status.title: ♻️ MDR Status
status.description: Define the status of the rule implementation according to use case development life cycle process.
markdownEnumDescriptions:
### ✍ In Design

🔑 **Identifier** : `DESIGN`

 







---

Under active functional design, without technical translation yet

### 👩‍💻 Under Active Development

🔑 **Identifier** : `DEVELOPMENT`

 







---

Under active technical implementation, going in exploratory rounds

### 🏗️ Ongoing Improvement

🔑 **Identifier** : `IMPROVING`

 







---

Rule is qualified functionally, but is undergoing refinment rounds

### 🚧 Staging

🔑 **Identifier** : `STAGING`

 







---

Deployed in staging environment for operational testing

### 📣 In Production

🔑 **Identifier** : `PRODUCTION`

 







---

Deployed in active production environment, potentially raising alerts

### ⚖️ Acceptance Gate

🔑 **Identifier** : `ACCEPTANCE`

 







---

A MDR is ready to go for PRODUCTION for CSIRC team. During ACCEPTANCE a CSIRC
analyst will handle the alert and will ensure the CSOC ticket and playbook are correct.


### 🛑 Disabled Rule

🔑 **Identifier** : `DISABLED`

 







---

Rule is still accessible, but not active in any environment

### 🗑️ Removed from Platforms

🔑 **Identifier** : `REMOVED`

 







---

Rule is fully deprecated, and only flagged under this status for archival purposes

contributors.title: 👥 Development Contributors
contributors.description: Individuals who supported creating, enriching or tuning the detection.

organizations.title: 🏢 Organizations
organizations.description: Override the default organizations the deployment will configure the reports onto.

watchlist.title: 🔎 Watchlist
watchlist.description: Override the default watchlist the report is added to.

report.title: ⚠️ Threat Report
report.description:
Default logic is to add the MDR to a report automatically generated from the same name.
It is also possible to deploy to a report with a different name.

severity.title: 💣 Custom Severity Score
severity.description: Allows to override the default severity mapping from the MDR with a custom value.

sentinel.title: Microsoft Sentinel
sentinel.description:
Microsoft Sentinel delivers intelligent security analytics
and threat intelligence across the enterprise. With Microsoft Sentinel, you
get a single solution for attack detection, threat visibility, proactive
hunting, and threat response.

schema.title: Schema identifier and version
schema.description: Identifier of the schema at its current version

status.description: Define the status of the rule implementation according to use case development life cycle process.

contributors.title: 👥 Development Contributors
contributors.description: Individuals who supported creating, enriching or tuning the detection.

trigger.title: 🔫 Trigger Operator
trigger.description:
The operation against the threshold that triggers alert rule.

⚠️ If you create a NRT rule, this value must be removed or commented out (NRT rules trigger an alert on the first match)

threshold.title: ⚖️ Event threshold
threshold.description:
If amount of events is higher than threshold (during the timeframe) the alert is triggered. 

⚠️ If you create a NRT rule, this value must be removed or commented out (NRT rules trigger an alert on the first match)

nrt.title: Near Real Time Rule
nrt.description:
NRT rules are hard-coded to run once every minute and capture events
ingested in the preceding minute, so as to be able to supply you with
information as up-to-the-minute as possible.

⚠️ You can not turn a ScheduledAlert into a NRT Rule or vice versa. Once
the MDR is deployed under this UUID, if it must be transformed into
a different type, a new UUID must be attributed and the previous rule
manually removed from Sentinel.

frequency.title: ⏱ Recurring Search Interval
frequency.description: Time intervals at which the scheduled search should be ran at, from 5m to up to 14days. Format is X d|h|m. If you create a NRT rule, this value must be removed or commented out.
frequency.markdownDescription:
Time intervals at which the scheduled search should be ran at

💡 _You can use `d`, `h` or `m` to represent `days`, `hours` and `minutes` respectively_

Note that Sentinel supports frequency intervals **from 5 minutes up to 14 days** only, translating to the
maximum values for lookback configuration : `14d`, `337h` or `20160m`

⚠️ If you create a NRT rule, this value must be removed or commented out (NRT rules work on the smallest possible timeframe)

lookback.title: ⌛ Lookback Configuration
lookback.description: Duration of logs to search in, up to 14 days. Format is X d|h|m. If you create a NRT rule, this value must be removed or commented out.
lookback.markdownDescription:
Duration of logs to search in. 

💡 _You can use `d`, `h` or `m` to represent `days`, `hours` and `minutes` respectively_

Note that Sentinel supports lookback periods **up to 14 days** only, translating to the
maximum values for lookback configuration : `14d`, `337h` or `20160m`

⚠️ If you create a NRT rule, this value must be removed or commented out (NRT rules work on the smallest possible timeframe)

alert.title: 🚨 Alert Configuration
alert.description: Alert Details allow analytic rules to have dynamic values for the Displayed name, Description, Tactics and Severity properties of the alert. By using dynamic alert details, the same rule can generate different incidents, for example with different severity. Also, the information displayed to the analyst can include variable information such as relevant entity names to  help the analyst understand the incident faster.

create_incident.title: Create Incident
create_incident.description: Create incidents from alerts triggered by this analytics rule

suppression.title: Alert Suppression
suppression.description: The duration to wait since last time this alert rule been triggered. Set to "false" to disable all suppression.

title.title: 🎫 Alert Display Name Format
title.description: Free text with field names embedded using the format {{columnName}}. Up to 256 chars and 3 placeholders.

description.title: 🔬 Alert Description Format
description.description: Free text with field names embedded using the format {{columnName}}. Up to 5000 chars and 3 placeholders

custom_details.title: 💬 Custom Details
custom_details.description: Surface particular event parameters and their values in alerts that comprise those events, by adding key-value pairs below.

key.description: Enter a name of your choosing that will appear as the field name in alerts.

column.description: Choose the column which value should be added as a custom detail. Must exist in the result of the query.

dynamic_properties.title: 💽 Alert Dynamic Properties
dynamic_properties.description: Override alert default properties, select an alert property from the Alert property drop-down list.

column.description: Choose the column which value should override the alert property. Must exist in the result of the query.

event.title: 📣 Event Grouping Details
event.description: Configure how rule query results are grouped into alerts.

anyOf.description: Trigger an alert for each event
Group all events into a single alert

alert.title: 🚨 Alert Grouping Details
alert.description: Set how the alerts that are triggered by this analytics rule, are grouped into incidents. Grouping alerts into incidents provides the context you need to respond and reduces the noise from single alerts.
alert.markdownDescription:
Set how the alerts that are triggered by this analytics rule, are grouped into incidents.
Grouping alerts into incidents provides the context you need to respond and reduces the noise from single alerts.

> 📌 Up to 150 alerts can be grouped into a single incident. If more than 150 alerts are generated, a new incident
will be created with the same incident details as the original, and the excess alerts will be grouped into the
new incident.

grouping_lookback.title: ⏳ Timeframe to Group Alerts
grouping_lookback.description: Limit the group to alerts created within the selected time frame.

matching.title: ❤️‍🔥 Matching Method
matching.description: Group alerts triggered by this analytics rule into a single incident using defined methods.

anyOf.description: Grouping alerts into a single incident if all the entities match (recommended)
Grouping all alerts triggered by this rule into a single incident

Grouping alerts into a single incident if the selected entities, custom details and alert details match.
⚠️ When using this option, ensure that the values you enter were already configured in the MDR.

group_by_entities.title: 🧊 Entity Alert Grouping
group_by_entities.description: A list of entity types to group by (when matchingMethod is Selected). Only entities defined in the current alert rule may be used.

group_by_alert_details.title: 💬 Alert Details Alert Grouping
group_by_alert_details.description: A list of alert details to group by (when matchingMethod is Selected)

group_by_custom_details.title: 💬 Custom Details Alert Grouping
group_by_custom_details.description: A list of custom details keys to group by (when matchingMethod is Selected). Only keys defined in the current alert rule may be used.

entities.title: 🧊 Entity Mappings
entities.description: Entity mapping is an integral part of the configuration of scheduled query analytics rules. It enriches the rules' output (alerts and incidents) with essential information that serves as the building blocks of any investigative processes and remedial actions that follow.

entity.title: 🧊 Sentinel Entity
entity.description: Entity Type for which attributes available as identifier are mapped to.
entity.markdownDescription:
Each mapped entity can identify **_up to ten entities._**

- If an alert contains more than ten items that correspond to a single entity
mapping, only the first ten will be recognized as entities and be able to be analyzed as such.
- This limitation applies to actual mappings, not to entity types. So if you have three
different mapped entities for IP addresses (say, source, destination, and gateway), each of
those mappings can accommodate ten entities.

anyOf.description: User account entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 👤 Account

_User account entity type_

Required identifiers : _Sid, Name, AadUserId, PUID, ObjectGuid_

**Strong identifiers of an account entity:**

- Name + UPNSuffix
- AadUserId
- Sid + Host (required for SIDs of builtin accounts)
- Sid (except for SIDs of builtin accounts)
- Name + NTDomain (unless NTDomain is a builtin domain, for example "Workgroup")
- Name + Host (if NTDomain is a builtin domain, for example "Workgroup")
- Name + DnsDomain
- PUID
- ObjectGuid

**Weak identifiers of an account entity:**

- Name

anyOf.description: Azure resource entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 💎 Azure Resource

_Azure resource entity type_

Required identifiers : _ResourceId_

**Strong identifiers of an Azure resource entity:**

- ResourceId

anyOf.description: Cloud app entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### ⛅ Cloud Application

_Cloud app entity type_

Required identifiers : _AppId, Name_

**Strong identifiers of a cloud application entity:**

- AppId (without InstanceName)
- Name (without InstanceName)
- AppId + InstanceName
- Name + InstanceName

anyOf.description: DNS entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🌐 Domain Name

_DNS entity type_

Required identifiers : _DomainName_

**Strong identifiers of a DNS entity:**

- DomainName + DnsServerIp + HostIpAddress

**Weak identifiers of a DNS entity:**

- DomainName + HostIpAddress

anyOf.description: System file entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 📄 File Entity

_System file entity type_

Required identifiers : _Name_

**Strong identifiers of a file entity:**

- Name + Directory
- Name + FileHash
- Name + Directory + FileHash

anyOf.description: File-hash entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🧩 File Hash

_File-hash entity type_

Required identifiers : _Algorithm + Value_

**Strong identifiers of a file hash entity:**

- Algorithm + Value

anyOf.description: Host entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🖥️ Host

_Host entity type_

Required identifiers : _HostName, NetBiosName, AzureID, OMSAgentID_

**Strong identifiers of a host entity:**

- HostName + NTDomain
- HostName + DnsDomain
- NetBiosName + NTDomain
- NetBiosName + DnsDomain
- AzureID
- OMSAgentID
- IoTDevice (not supported for entity mapping)

**Weak identifiers of a host entity:**

- HostName
- NetBiosName

anyOf.description: IoT device entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🖲️ IoT device

_IoT device entity type_

Required identifiers : _DeviceId_

**Strong identifiers of an IoT device entity:**

- IoTHub + DeviceId

**Weak identifiers of a IoT device entity:** 

- DeviceId (without IoTHub)

anyOf.description: IP address entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🌐 IP Address

_IP address entity type_

Required identifiers : _Address_

**Strong identifiers of an IP entity:**

- Address

anyOf.description: Mail cluster entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 📩 Mail Cluster

_Mail cluster entity type_

Required identifiers : _Query, Source_

**Strong identifiers of a mail cluster entity:**

- Query + Source

anyOf.description: Mail message address entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 📧 Mail Message

_Mail message entity type_

Required identifiers : _NetworkMessageId, Recipient_

**Strong identifiers of a mail message entity:**

- NetworkMessageId + Recipient

anyOf.description: Mailbox entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 📬 Mailbox

_Mailbox entity type_

Required identifiers : _MailboxPrimaryAddress_

**Strong identifiers of a mailbox entity:**

- MailboxPrimaryAddress

anyOf.description: Malware entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### ☣️ Malware

_Malware entity type_

Required identifiers : _Name_

**Strong identifiers of a malware entity:**

- Name + Category

anyOf.description: Process entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### ⚙️ Process

_Process entity type_

Required identifiers : _CommandLine, ProcessId_

**Strong identifiers of a process entity:**

- Host + ProcessId + CreationTimeUtc
- Host + ParentProcessId + CreationTimeUtc + CommandLine
- Host + ProcessId + CreationTimeUtc + ImageFile
- Host + ProcessId + CreationTimeUtc + ImageFile.FileHash

**Weak identifiers of a process entity:**

- ProcessId + CreationTimeUtc + CommandLine (and no Host)
- ProcessId + CreationTimeUtc + ImageFile (and no Host)

anyOf.description: Registry key entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🗄️ Registry Key

_Registry key entity type_

Required identifiers : _Hive, Key_

**Strong identifiers of a registry key entity:**

- Hive + Key

anyOf.description: Registry value entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🗃️ Registry Value

_Registry value entity type_

Required identifiers : _Name_

**Strong identifiers of a registry value entity:**

- Key + Name

**Weak identifiers of a registry value entity:**

- Name (without Key)

anyOf.description: Security group entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🔐 Security Group

_Security group entity type_

Required identifiers : _DistinguishedName, SID, ObjectGuid_

**Strong identifiers of a security group entity:**

- DistinguishedName
- SID
- ObjectGuid

anyOf.description: Sumission mail entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 📨 Submission Mail

_Submission mail entity type_

Required identifiers : _SubmissionId, NetworkMessageId, Recipient, Submitter_

**Strong identifiers of a submission mail entity:**

- SubmissionId
- Submitter
- NetworkMessageId
- Recipient

anyOf.description: URL entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🔗 URL

_URL entity type_

Required identifiers : _Url_

**Strong identifiers of a URL entity:**

- Url (when an absolute URL)

**Weak identifiers of a URL entity:** 

- Url (when a relative URL)

anyOf.description: Sentinel Entities entity type
anyOf.markdownDescription:
### 🧊 Sentinel Entities

_Sentinel Entities entity type_

Maps against a list of the entities. This list can include a combination of entities of different types.

> ⚠️ This entity type is not well known or documented, and should be considered experimental. Make
sure to test in the GUI to confirm the correct behaviour before using this feature.

Required identifiers : _Entities_

mappings.title: 🗺️ Entity Mappings
mappings.description: Identifier and Column combination for the chosen entity type

identifier.title: 📍 Entity Identifier
identifier.description: Identifier used to provide identification for the chosen entity.
identifier.markdownDescription:
Each one of the identifiers in the **required identifiers** column is minimally necessary to identify its entity.
However, a required identifier might not, by itself, be sufficient to provide _unique_ identification.
The more identifiers used, the greater the likelihood of unique identification. You can use up to
three identifiers for a single entity mapping.

For best results - for guaranteed unique identification - you should use identifiers from the **strongest
identifiers** column whenever possible. The use of multiple strong identifiers enables correlation
between strong identifiers from varying data sources and schemas. This in turn allows Microsoft
Sentinel to provide more comprehensive insights for a given entity.

column.title: 🪘 Data Table Column
column.description: The column name to be mapped to the identifier. Note that it must be a valid column name available in the query result from the KQL chosen.

splunk.title: Splunk Enterprise
splunk.description:
Splunk Enterprise enables you to search, analyze and
visualize your data to quickly act on insights from across your technology landscape.

schema.title: Schema identifier and version
schema.description: Identifier of the schema at its current version

status.title: ♻️ MDR Status
status.description: Define the status of the rule implementation according to use case development life cycle process.
markdownEnumDescriptions:
### ✍ In Design

🔑 **Identifier** : `DESIGN`

 







---

Under active functional design, without technical translation yet

### 👩‍💻 Under Active Development

🔑 **Identifier** : `DEVELOPMENT`

 







---

Under active technical implementation, going in exploratory rounds

### 🏗️ Ongoing Improvement

🔑 **Identifier** : `IMPROVING`

 







---

Rule is qualified functionally, but is undergoing refinment rounds

### 🚧 Staging

🔑 **Identifier** : `STAGING`

 







---

Deployed in staging environment for operational testing

### 📣 In Production

🔑 **Identifier** : `PRODUCTION`

 







---

Deployed in active production environment, potentially raising alerts

### ⚖️ Acceptance Gate

🔑 **Identifier** : `ACCEPTANCE`

 







---

A MDR is ready to go for PRODUCTION for CSIRC team. During ACCEPTANCE a CSIRC
analyst will handle the alert and will ensure the CSOC ticket and playbook are correct.


### 🛑 Disabled Rule

🔑 **Identifier** : `DISABLED`

 







---

Rule is still accessible, but not active in any environment

### 🗑️ Removed from Platforms

🔑 **Identifier** : `REMOVED`

 







---

Rule is fully deprecated, and only flagged under this status for archival purposes

contributors.title: 👥 Development Contributors
contributors.description: Individuals who supported creating, enriching or tuning the detection.

threshold.title: ⚖️ Event threshold
threshold.description: If amount of events is higher than threshold (during the timeframe) the alert is triggered. Default = 0.

fields.title: 🔖 Throttling Fields
fields.description: Fields to check for matching values in events. Events with the same value for these fields are suppressed.

duration.title: ⌛ Throttling Period
duration.description: How long do discard new alerts that have the same characteristics (duplicate alerts), based on the fields defined below in hours/days. Default same as scheduling (value = 1h).

cron.title: ⏲ Scheduled search cron scheduling
cron.description: Cron Expression describing the scheduling for running the search.

frequency.title: ⏱ Recurring Search Interval
frequency.description: Time intervals at which the scheduled search should be ran at. Warning: due to implementation details, only the following intervals are allowed for Splunk : 1-59m , 1-23h , 1-30d . For more complex scheduling, use the cron option instead.
frequency.markdownDescription:
Time intervals at which the scheduled search should be ran at. ⚠️ **Warning :** due to implementation details, only the following intervals are allowed for Splunk : 1-59m , 1-23h , 1-30d .

Frequency is translated into cron expressions.

**Examples**
- 15m is translated into `*/15 * * * *`, or _At every 15th minute_
- 4h is translated into `MM */4 * * *`, or _At minute MM past every 4th hour_
- 2d is translated into `MM HH */2 * *`, or _At HH:MM on every 2nd day-of-month_

👉 HH:MM is a timestamp we take to allow a correct cron setup. This timestamp has 2 default modes setup in Splunk's config.yaml entry: `random`, which takes random hours and minutes at each deployment,  which can be preferable for performances, and `current` which take the current time of the **latest** deployment.

You can override this behaviour with `custom_time`, hidden from the template but accessible with `Control+Space`. There you can setup a custom timestamp (note that hours only matter in the case for frequency with days, and that when the frequency is minutes it won't have an effect)
For more complex scheduling, use the cron option instead.

custom_time.title: Custom Frequency Setup
custom_time.description:
Customize the base time that the frequency takes as an anchor. Expects HHhmm format.
See frequency description for more explanation in how they interact.

lookback.title: ⌛ Lookback Configuration
lookback.description: Duration of logs to search in

notable.title: 🎖️ Notable Event Settings
notable.description: Configuration for notable events generated by the alert

event.title: 📣 Notable Event Configuration
event.description: Describes attributes related to the notable event

title.title: 🪪 Notable Event Name
title.example: New Abnormal Credentials added to Azure AD from user $logonuser

drilldown.title: 🕵 Drilldown search configuration
drilldown.description: Describes attributes related to drilldown search accompanying the notable event.

security_domain.title: ⚠️ DEPRECATION WARNING
security_domain.description: ⚠️ DEPRECATED : security_domain is now nested under the notable block

risk.title: Splunk Risk Analysis
risk.description:
Risk notables are automatically generated when you run a risk incident rule,
which associates risk scores with a system, user, or other risk objects.

message.title: 💬 Risk Message
message.description:
A unique message to describe the risk activity, which can use fields
from the risk event surrounded by "$".

risk_objects.title: 💣 Risk Objects
risk_objects.description:
A unique message to describe the risk activity, which can use
fields from the risk event surrounded by "$". For example:
Suspicious Activity to $domain$

field.description: Splunk field containing the risk object

score.description:
A number that represents the risk level of a
specific risk object. Risk events have a default score
that you can modify using risk factors.

threat_objects.title: 🔪 Risk Objects
threat_objects.description:
Deviant behavior patterns of a risk object or entity,
which indicate a security breach. For example: The Domain
threat object tracks the behavior of the domain across all risk objects.

field.description: Splunk field containing the threat object

query.title: 🔍 Splunk SPL Detection Query
query.example: | search (code=10 OR code=29 OR code=43) host!="localhost" xqp>5

advanced.title: 🦾 Advanced Edit custom parameters
advanced.description: Support for any parameter able to edited through Advanced Edit. Ensure that the naming and data inputed is as expected from Splunk.
